Thanks for tracking this down. I had indeed suspected an overflow due to the negative timestamp in the error message. Can we fix the code so that overflow is not possible? That would be preferable.

@ijuma sure so basically just solve this case by saturating addition (Long.MaxValue + x == Long.MaxValue) right?

edit: nvm yea it's the only approach that makes sense :D .. it's a compare only anyways
@ijuma minimal solution added, let me know if you want this done in a more general way :)

@ijuma @becketqin I have addressed all the comments and rebased the patch onto trunk. Do you have time to review the latest patch?

@lindong28 @becketqin I think this PR is causing the following transient test failure:

```text
kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest.testMaxPollIntervalMsDelayInRevocation

java.lang.IllegalStateException: No entry found for connection 2
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClusterConnectionStates.nodeState(ClusterConnectionStates.java:166)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClusterConnectionStates.connectionState(ClusterConnectionStates.java:156)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.NetworkClient.connectionFailed(NetworkClient.java:232)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.checkDisconnects(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:356)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.poll(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:231)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.pollNoWakeup(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:259)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator$HeartbeatThread.run(AbstractCoordinator.java:911)
```

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-trunk/1685/testReport/junit/kafka.api/PlaintextConsumerTest/testMaxPollIntervalMsDelayInRevocation/
Thanks for the PR. Can you please target trunk?

@ijuma Yes, I discovered this when rebasing KIP-107 and have fixed it there. Let me submit a separate pull request to fix this problem.
Thanks!
@ijuma cleaned up as suggested :)

KAFKA-4820 allows new request to be enqueued to `unsent` by user thread while some other thread does `poll(...)`. This causes problem in the following scenario:

- Thread A calls `poll(...)` and is blocked on `select(...)`
- Thread B enqueues a request into `unsent` of ConsumerNetworkClient for node `N`
- Thread A calls `checkDisconnects(now)` -> `client.connectionFailed(N)`
- Because no attempts have been made to connection to node `N` yet, there is no state for node `N` and `connectionFailed(N)` would throw exception.

The solution is to only consider a connection has failed if attempts have been made to connect to this node AND the connection state is `DISCONNECTED`. Note that this problem only occurs when one thread is able to enqueue requests while another thread is in the process of `poll(...)`

@ijuma @becketqin Can you review this patch?
Thanks, LGTM.

One meta comment:

Instead of making this change, could we just modify line 258 to be

```
this.logPrefix = String.format("stream-thread [%s]", threadClientId);
```

The reason I was a bit concerned about this approach is that it complicates the logic of generating the threadClientId, which is now depending whether users set the clientId in their config or not. cc @sharad-develop @mjsax
LGTM

@ijuma haha yea makes a lot more sense than "verify by 1000 iterations pass now" :) On it adding a test then :)

@guozhangwang I am not sure. `Thread#getName()` is called on multiple places in the code, and each should encode the `application.id` IMHO.

Furthermore, I am not sure what you mean by "threadClientId, which is now depending whether users set the clientId in their config or not"? Isn't it depended on the config anyway, ie, even before this change?
As you replaced this with https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2642 can you please close this PR. Thx.

@ijuma hmm one problem :) This is coming from a long overflow, but only hits us because `now` is set to a value before the create time in failure runs.

If you look at the [first screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6490959/23581016/f1852054-010c-11e7-9a7f-574937b5060f.png) (in the PR description) you can see `now > this.createdMs` does not always hold in practice (I can easily reproduce this running the test in a loop ... only the `linger == 1h` actually fixed the issue :().
The overflow in this case is not fixed by `now - this.createdMs - lingerMs`, neither is it by my initial solution of `now - Math.max(this.createdMs + lingerMs, lingerMs))`. 
What you would need here is `Math.max(0, now - this.createdMs) - lingerMs` (this would be safe for any positive lingerMs imo).
Sorry for missing this initially, for 1h linger time this didn't matter since the small negative difference there was just eaten up by 3.6M `ms`.

But my question would be: Is `now < this.createdMs` even a valid case to handle here? (In that case I have it fixed by `Math.max(0, now - this.createdMs) - lingerMs` + UT :) )

@ijuma pushed my fix + test case, probably easier to understand from that than form my explaination :D 
But that said ... imo it makes sense to properly handle negative timestamp differences here when talking about expiration (just natural to say X expires at timestamp Y so timestamp befor X is not expired) in general.
